entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 5 at 3:31AM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
entry.summary:
Sustained winds over Northeast Georgia of 10 to 15 MPH can be expected along with gusts to 25 to 30 MPH. Relative Humidity values will drop into the 25 to 30 percent range. With dry fuels, high fire danger conditions can be expected.
Please refer to your local burn permitting authorities whether you may burn outdoors. If you do burn outside, use extreme caution.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Rabun; Habersham; Stephens; Franklin; Hart; Elbert

cap:parameter.value: INCREASED FIRE DANGER IN EFFECT FROM NOON EDT TODAY THROUGH THIS EVENING

entry.title: High Wind Watch issued April 5 at 1:17AM MDT until April 7 at 6:00PM MDT by NWS Goodland KS
entry.summary:
* WHAT...South winds at 30 to 45 mph with gusts up to 65 mph possible this evening through Saturday morning, shifting to the west Saturday afternoon. West to northwest winds at 30 to 50 mph with gusts up to 70 mph possible Saturday night into Sunday.
* WHERE...Entire Tri-State area.
* WHEN...This evening through Sunday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Dangerous travel conditions are likely over much, or all, of the Tri-state area this weekend. High winds may also move loose debris, damage property and cause power outages.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Southerly winds will rapidly shift to the west as a cold front sweeps eastward across the area late Saturday morning and Saturday afternoon. Strong west to northwest winds will follow, in the wake of the front. The abrupt nature of the wind shift may catch motorists off guard. Widespread, significant reductions in visibility associated with blowing dust are possible during the frontal passage. A prolonged period of strong, perhaps damaging, west to northwest winds are possible Saturday evening into the day on Sunday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Yuma County; Kit Carson County; Cheyenne County; Cheyenne; Rawlins; Decatur; Norton; Sherman; Thomas; Sheridan; Graham; Wallace; Logan; Gove; Greeley; Wichita; Dundy; Hitchcock; Red Willow

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued April 5 at 12:00AM PDT until April 5 at 10:00AM PDT by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow. 2 and 8 inches will be possible north and west of Susanville and Eagle Lake. Up to 10 inches possible where banded snow showers become intensified. Light snow amounts of 1 to 2 inches for areas below 5000 feet south of Susanville.
* WHERE...In California, Lassen-Eastern Plumas-Eastern Sierra Counties and Surprise Valley California. In Nevada, Northern Washoe County.
* WHEN...Until 10 AM PDT Friday.
* IMPACTS...Roads, and especially bridges and overpasses, will likely become slick and hazardous. Plan on slippery road conditions. The hazardous conditions could impact the Friday morning commute.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Impacts to areas along Highway 44 near Bogard, Highway 299 through Bieber, US-395 north of Ravendale.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 5 at 3:00AM EDT until April 7 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Mount Holly NJ
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in New Jersey...
Passaic River Above Singac affecting Essex, Passaic and Morris Counties.
For the Passaic River...including Singac...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Passaic River above Singac.
* WHEN...Until Sunday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 8.5 feet, Portions of the Wayne Town Center parking lot begin to flood. Hobson Avenue and Riverlawn Drive in Wayne begin to flood. Fairfield Road, Fayette Avenue, and Riversedge Road in Wayne can flood as water backs up the Pompton River. Lincoln Boulevard in Lincoln Park can also flood due to backwater up the Pompton river. The Pequannock River Park also floods. At 9.0 feet, Two Bridges Road in Fairfield is subject to closures. At 9.5 feet, Camp Lane and Marginal Road in Fairfield begins to flood. At 10.0 feet, Two Bridges Road in Fairfield begins to flood. Finns Drive, Siesta Drive, and Market street in Wayne are all susceptible to flooding. William Street, Louis Street, and Zeliff Avenue in Little Falls can begin to flood. Portions of Lincoln Park become impassable. The Meadows Golf Club in Lincoln Park floods.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 2:45 AM EDT Friday the stage was 9.3 feet and rising. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 2:45 AM EDT Friday was 9.3 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 9.4 feet this afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage early Sunday morning. - Flood stage is 8.5 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 9.4 feet on 12/23/2018. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Essex, NJ; Morris, NJ; Passaic, NJ

cap:parameter.value: FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL SUNDAY MORNING

entry.title: Coastal Flood Advisory issued April 5 at 2:59AM EDT until April 5 at 4:00AM EDT by NWS Wakefield VA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Up to one foot of inundation above ground level in low- lying areas near shorelines and tidal waterways.
* WHERE...Dorchester, Wicomico and Somerset Counties.
* WHEN...Until 4 AM EDT early this morning.
* IMPACTS...Shallow flooding is expected in the most vulnerable locations near the waterfront and shoreline resulting in a low threat of property damage. Expect up to one foot of water above ground level in low lying, vulnerable areas. Some roads and low lying property including parking lots, parks and lawns near the waterfront will experience shallow flooding.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Dorchester

cap:parameter.value: COASTAL FLOOD ADVISORY NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL 4 AM EDT EARLY THIS MORNING

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 5 at 2:57AM EDT by NWS Mount Holly NJ
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in New Jersey...
Passaic River At Little Falls affecting Essex and Passaic Counties.
For the Passaic River...including Little Falls...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Passaic River at Little Falls.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 5.5 feet, The lower end of East-Holsman Street in Paterson, closest to the river, begins to flood. At 6.0 feet, Portions of Hoffman Grove in Wayne sustain some nuisance flooding. At 6.5 feet, Low lying areas in the vicinity of Two Bridges in Wayne are flooded. The lower end of Bergen Street in Paterson, closest to the river, begins to flood. At 7.0 feet, Minor flooding begins in Lincoln Park, Wayne and Little Falls. At 8.0 feet, Flooding occurs in the "Old" Wayne area of Wayne. entry.title: Wind Advisory issued April 4 at 8:02PM HST until April 5 at 6:00PM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
...WIND ADVISORY FOR PORTIONS OF ALL ISLANDS THROUGH FRIDAY AFTERNOON... ...HIGH WIND WARNING FOR LEEWARD KOHALA ON THE BIG ISLAND THROUGH FRIDAY AFTERNOON...
.A strong high pressure system to the north of the islands, combined with a trough to the northwest, is producing strong and gusty trade winds. These winds are expected to continue into Friday. A High Wind Warning was issued for the leeward Kohala area on the Big Island, other islands will see Wind Advisory conditions through at least Friday afternoon.
* WHAT...East winds 20 to 35 mph with localized gusts over 50 mph.
* WHERE...Winds will be strongest through gaps and passes, over ridges and downslope of mountains. Some areas particularly prone to these gusty winds will be the Waimea and Kohala areas of the Big Island, West Maui and the higher elevations of Lanai.
* WHEN...Until 6 PM HST Friday.
* IMPACTS...Winds this strong can tear off shingles, knock down tree branches, blow away tents and awnings and make it difficult to steer, especially for drivers of high profile vehicles.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 4 at 10:52PM PDT by NWS Elko NV
entry.summary:
Radar is indicating bands of light to locally moderate snowfall across portions of west-central Nevada, including locations like Austin, Battle Mountain, and Winnemucca. Nevada Department of Transportation webcams and remote observation platforms are showing visibility of one mile or less in some spots along with snow covered roadways. Some of these roads include the higher passes and summits along I-80 in Humboldt and northern Lander counties, as well as US Highway 95 and State Route 305 from Battle Mountain to Austin. If driving through these areas tonight, please use caution as roads may quickly become snow covered and slippery and drivers may encounter rapid reductions to visibility along their routes.
Visit www.weather.gov/elko for the latest weather information.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Humboldt County; Northern Lander County and Northern Eureka County; Southern Lander County and Southern Eureka County

entry.title: Flood Advisory issued April 5 at 12:02AM EDT by NWS Pittsburgh PA
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Pittsburgh PA has issued a Flood Advisory for the following rivers in Pennsylvania...
Ohio River At Pittsburgh affecting Allegheny County.
* WHAT...Flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues, but levels have dropped below Minor Flood Stage (25ft). The peak stage observed was 28.37ft between the hours of 6:05 AM and 10:35 AM (local) Friday April 4th.
* WHERE...Ohio River at Pittsburgh.
* WHEN...From early this morning until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 18.0 feet, Water begins to flow onto the Monongahela Parking Wharf. At 19.0 feet, Water begins to flow onto the North Shore riverwalk between the stadiums. At 19.5 feet, The Monongahela Parking Wharf is completely flooded. At 20.0 feet, Water is up to one foot deep in the lower areas of the North Shore Riverwalk. At 22.0 feet, The Tenth Street Bypass floods. At 22.5 feet, The fountain plaza is flooded. At 24.0 feet, Water enters the outer pool of the fountain. At 24.9 feet, Water entes the inner pool of the fountain. At 25.0 feet, The Parkway Central (also known as the bathtub) is closed by flooding. Lower North Side businesses are affected. At 26.0 feet, State Correctional Institution Pittsburgh is impacted.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:45 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 24.4 feet. - Bankfull stage is 18.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall to 17.0 feet Tuesday evening. - Action stage is 18.0 feet. - Flood stage is 25.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Allegheny, PA

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 4 at 11:35PM EDT by NWS Jackson KY
entry.summary:
Mixed rain and snow showers in the lower elevations and snow showers above 2500 feet will impact the area overnight into Friday morning. Above 2500 feet on Pine Mountain and Black Mountain, some light accumulations of a dusting to around an inch are forecast, generally on grassy and elevated surfaces. However, during the heavier snow showers, some roadways above 2500 feet could become snow- or slush-covered for a time, with this most probable on roadways above 3000 feet that cross Black Mountain in Harlan County such as KY 179 and KY 160. Other roadways that may be affected by winter travel include US 119, US 421, KY 38, KY 2010, and the Little Shepherd Trail.
If traveling across Pine and Black Mountains overnight through Friday morning, expect some slick spots. Slow down and allow extra time to reach your destination.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Harlan; Letcher

cap:parameter.value: Minor Snow Accumulations Possible Above 2500 Feet Overnight Through Friday Morning

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued April 4 at 9:10PM MDT until April 6 at 8:00PM MDT by NWS El Paso Tx/Santa Teresa NM
entry.summary:
...CRITICAL FIRE WEATHER CONDITIONS MAY DEVELOP SATURDAY AFTERNOON...
.A combination of increasing west/northwest winds behind a passing cold front, low relative humidity, and continued drying of fine fuels will potentially produce critical fire weather conditions across portions of south-central New Mexico and far west Texas on Saturday. Fuel moisture is dry enough along the desert lowlands to pose a risk of wildfire starts.
* AFFECTED AREA...Texas Fire Weather Zones 055 El Paso County and 056 Hudspeth County. New Mexico Fire Weather Zone 112 South Central Lowlands and Southern Rio Grande Valley/BLM/GLZ.
* TIMING...Beginning late Saturday morning into early Saturday evening.
* WINDS...West 25 to 35 mph with gusts up to 50 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...10 to 15 percent.
* TEMPERATURES...Highs in the upper 50s to lower 60s.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.
entry.cap:areaDesc: South Central Lowlands And Southern Rio Grande Valley; El Paso; Hudspeth

cap:parameter.value: FIRE WEATHER WATCH REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM SATURDAY AFTERNOON AND EVENING FOR GUSTY WINDS AND LOW HUMIDITY FOR SOUTH-CENTRAL NEW MEXICO AND FAR WEST TEXAS

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued April 4 at 9:34PM CDT until April 5 at 7:00PM CDT by NWS Bismarck ND
entry.summary:
...FIRE WEATHER WATCH FOR PARTS OF NORTHERN AND CENTRAL NORTH DAKOTA FRIDAY AFTERNOON INTO FRIDAY EVENING...
.Critical fire weather conditions are possible on Friday afternoon into Friday evening across parts of northern and central North Dakota. Minimum relative humidity is expected to drop into the 18 to 25 percent range, with the lowest values in north central North Dakota. Southeast winds will be sustained from 25 to 30 mph, with gusts to 45 mph.
* WINDS...Southeast 25 to 30 mph with gusts up to 45 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 18 percent.
* AFFECTED AREA...Parts of northern and central North Dakota.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that ignite will spread rapidly and become difficult to control or suppress.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Burke; Renville; Bottineau; Rolette; Mountrail; Ward; McHenry; Pierce; McLean; Sheridan; Wells; Burleigh; Kidder

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 4 at 9:55PM EDT until April 7 at 7:08PM EDT by NWS Pittsburgh PA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Ohio...
Wills Creek At Cambridge affecting Guernsey County.
Stillwater Creek At Uhrichsville affecting Tuscarawas County.
* WHAT...Major flooding is occurring and major flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Wills Creek at Cambridge.
* WHEN...Until Sunday evening.
* IMPACTS...At 15.0 feet, Overflowing of poor drainage and low lying areas will result in minor flooding along wills creek. At 16.0 feet, Basement flooding begins through floor drains and other sewer connections. Local interruptions in sanitary service may occur along Gordon's Run from 3rd Street to 6th Street. At 17.0 feet, Water overflows wills Creek Valley Road to a depth of 2 feet. Water reaches a depth of 1 foot on North Eighth Street. At 18.0 feet, Flood waters begin effecting apartments along Wills Creek Valley Road. Southgate Parkway will also begin flooding near Woodlawn Avenue. At 20.0 feet, Flood waters reach residential areas on the west side of Cambridge. At 22.0 feet, The North 8th Street Bridge near the school campus is impassable. Flood waters reach Wills Creek Valley Drive near the County Road 35 Bridge. The north side of Cambridge is close to being cut off from access. Water from Wills Creek will flood the west end of Cambridge.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:15 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 20.9 feet. - Bankfull stage is 13.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 9:15 PM EDT Thursday was 21.1 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 20.9 feet just after midnight tonight. It will then fall below flood stage early Sunday afternoon. - Flood stage is 15.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 21.3 feet on 04/04/2024. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Guernsey, OH

entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Ohio...
Wills Creek At Cambridge affecting Guernsey County.
Stillwater Creek At Uhrichsville affecting Tuscarawas County.
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Stillwater Creek at Uhrichsville.
* WHEN...Until late Monday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 10.0 feet, Stillwater Creek comes out of its banks in several locations resulting in overflowing in poor drainage areas. Minor flooding of low lying areas begins. Little Stillwater Creek will flood most of Phac Park along with portions of Wilson Road in Dennison. At 12.9 feet, Numerous low land areas are flooded. Stillwater Creek begins to flood portions of Newport Street in Uhrichsville. Homes along Park Drive begin to flood. Sections of Wilson Road near Phac Park are flooded. At 13.3 feet, Flood waters reach Newport Avenue in Uhrichsville as well as East 12th Street and North Main Street half way to East 11th Street. Phac Park along Little Stillwater Creek in Dennison is flooded.

Pawcatuck River At Westerly affecting Washington and New London Counties.
Taunton River Near Bridgewater affecting Plymouth and Bristol Counties.

For the Sudbury River...including Saxonville...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Charles River...including Dover...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Pawtuxet River...including Cranston...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Pawcatuck River...including Wood River Junction, Westerly... Minor flooding is forecast. For the Taunton River...including Bridgewater...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Wood River...including Hope Valley...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Taunton River near Bridgewater.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 9.0 feet, Backwater flooding from the Taunton River will cause flooding of lower Purchade Brook in Middleboro. This will cause Woloski Park to become impassable by most vehicles for an extended period of time. Beware of the dangers of crossing flooded roadways. The water may be deeper than you think. Floodwaters have the ability to damage roadways. Heed the advice of local officials, and evacuate if asked to do so.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:45 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 8.4 feet. - Bankfull stage is 8.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 8:45 PM EDT Thursday was 8.4 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 9.0 feet early tomorrow afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage early Sunday afternoon. - Flood stage is 8.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 4 at 9:51PM EDT by NWS Pittsburgh PA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Ohio...
Muskingum River At Coshocton affecting Coshocton County.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Muskingum River at Coshocton.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 13.0 feet, Water reaches low lying areas between Tuscarawas and Walhonding Rivers just upstream of the confluence of the two rivers. At 15.0 feet, Low areas are flooded and water reaches a few homes along Route 16 south of Coshocton and along County Route 1A north of Coshocton. At 16.0 feet, Flood waters begin to affect the Lake Park area along the Walhonding River and begins backwater flooding along Mill Creek north of Lake Park and along Route 83. Flood waters will begin to enter yards in low-lying areas along County Route 1A.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:00 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 13.2 feet. - Bankfull stage is 13.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage late Sunday morning and continue rising to a crest of 15.3 feet early Monday morning. - Flood stage is 15.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 16.9 feet on 02/13/2019. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 4 at 9:50PM EDT until April 5 at 2:30PM EDT by NWS Pittsburgh PA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Ohio River at Wellsville.
* WHEN...Until early tomorrow afternoon.
* IMPACTS...At 7.0 feet, Preparations begin for activating pumps for local flood protection project At 9.0 feet, Pumping operations begin at the corps of engineers local flood protection project At 11.0 feet, The parking lot of the marina outside the river wall begins to flood. This area is not protected by the flood wall and the installation of flood gates at the Corps of Engineers flood protection project. At 13.0 feet, The picnic pavilion at the marina on Little Yellow Creek begins to flood. This area is not protected by the flood wall and the installation of flood gates at the Corps of Engineers flood protection project. At 14.0 feet, Residential basements flood on Wells Avenue at the north end of town. This area is not protected by the flood wall and the installation of flood gates at the Corps of Engineers local flood protection project. At 16.0 feet, Little Yellow Creek reaches bankful at the Lisbon Street Bridge. This area is not protected by the flood wall and the installation of flood gates at the Corps of Engineers local flood protection project.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:35 AM EDT Thursday the stage was 14.0 feet. - Bankfull stage is 11.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 9:35 AM EDT Thursday was 14.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage tomorrow morning and continue falling to 3.6 feet Tuesday evening. - Flood stage is 11.0 feet. - Flood History...No available flood history. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 4 at 9:50PM EDT until April 6 at 4:26AM EDT by NWS Pittsburgh PA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Ohio River at Wheeling.
* WHEN...Until early Saturday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 34.0 feet, Sewers begin to back up in the lower end of Wheeling Island. At 36.0 feet, Flooding begins in the vicinity or 25th and Market Streets, 34th and Market Streets, 36th and Chapline Streets in Wheeling. Water covers the lower parking lot at the Wheeling Island Casino. At 36.6 feet, Wheeling Downs Racetrack on Wheeling Island floods. At 37.7 feet, Basement flooding begins in businesses along Main Street. At 38.0 feet, Portions of Jacob and Wood Streets, south of 43rd Street begin to flood. Wheeling island Casino has to be closed. At 39.0 feet, The southern tip of Wheeling Island including Wheeling Downs Racetrack and Gaming and Wheeling Stadium are flooded. At 40.0 feet, Backwater flooding begins to affect Main Street near the water treatment plant in Wheeling. At 41.0 feet, Water street in Wheeling is flooded near the intersctions with 12th, 21st, 45th, and 48th Streets. At 42.0 feet, Flooding reaches the intersection of 39th and McColloch Streets and the intersection of Georgia and North Front Streets in Wheeling. At 42.7 feet, Much of southern half of Wheeling Island is flooded and up to Erie Street on the northern half of the island. Low lying sections of South Wheeling are flooded.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 9:30 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 41.5 feet. - Bankfull stage is 36.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 9:30 PM EDT Thursday was 41.5 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 41.5 feet just after midnight tonight. entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued April 4 at 3:34PM HST until April 5 at 6:00PM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
entry.summary:
...HIGH SURF ADVISORY FOR EAST FACING SHORES OF KAUAI OAHU MOLOKAI MAUI AND THE BIG ISLAND UNTIL 6 PM HST FRIDAY...
.Strong trade winds near and upstream of the islands will generate large and rough surf along east facing shores.
* WHAT...Surf of 8 to 12 feet.
* WHERE...East facing shores of Kauai, Oahu, Molokai, Maui, and the Big Island.
* WHEN...Until 6 PM HST Friday, though this advisory may be extended later.
* IMPACTS...Moderate. Strong breaking waves and strong currents will make swimming dangerous.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 4 at 9:30PM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Florida...
Santa Fe River At Three Rivers Estates affecting Columbia, Gilchrist and Suwannee Counties.
Additional information is available at https://water.weather.gov/ahps2/forecasts.php?wfo=jax.
The next statement will be issued Friday evening at 930 PM EDT.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Santa Fe River at Three Rivers Estates.
* WHEN...Until further notice.
* IMPACTS...At 16.0 feet, Lowland flooding begins on SW Santa Fe Drive south of Santa Fe Road in Columbia County. At 16.3 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission begins enforcement of a no wake zone on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream of the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to the confluence with the Suwannee River and on the Ichetucknee River upstream to the US 27 bridge. At 17.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences on Santa Fe Road in Columbia County and on River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.0 feet, Water begins to flood River Run Road in Suwannee County. At 18.8 feet, Florida Fish and Wildlife Commission expands the no wake zone restriction further upstream on the Santa Fe River from the unnamed island 1.5 miles downstream on the Wilson's Spring Boat Ramp to one-half mile upstream of the State Road 47 bridge. At 19.0 feet, Water begins to enter backyards of residences along the Ichetucknee River. At 19.8 feet, Waters begins to affect homes in the Hollingsworth Bluff area at State Route 47. At 20.0 feet, Access to homes on Santa Fe Road below SW Riverside Avenue becomes restricted in Columbia. Flooding begins on Santa Fe and Wilson Springs Road.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:00 PM EDT Thursday the stage was 17.4 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to 18.3 feet early Tuesday afternoon. Additional rises are possible thereafter. - Flood stage is 17.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Columbia, FL; Gilchrist, FL; Suwannee, FL

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued April 4 at 8:19PM CDT by NWS Lincoln IL
entry.summary:
ESFILX
This hydrologic outlook includes the following river in Illinois:
Illinois River...
River levels continue to rise on the Illinois River in response to recent rainfall. By Saturday night, they will be near flood stage at Henry, which is 23 feet. However, there remains some uncertainty as to whether or not it actually reaches that level.
People with interests in the river near Henry should continue to monitor later forecasts. Once there is more certainty about the river forecasts, a flood warning or statement will be issued if the threat materializes.

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued April 4 at 6:10PM MST by NWS Phoenix AZ
entry.summary:
The South Coast AQMD has extended an air quality alert due to increased particle pollution from blowing dust. The air quality alert is in effect through tomorrow night.
In areas directly impacted by high levels of windblown dust, limit your exposure by remaining indoors with windows and doors closed and avoiding vigorous physical activity. Run your air conditioner or an air purifier. If temperatures allow, avoid using whole house fans or swamp coolers that bring in outside air.
Exposure to high particle pollution levels can cause serious health problems, including asthma attacks, heart and lung disease symptoms, and increased risk of respiratory infections. People with heart or lung diseases should follow their doctor's advice for dealing with episodes of unhealthy air quality. Children, older adults, and people with respiratory or heart disease should avoid prolonged exposure and strenuous activities when particle pollution levels are high.
To help minimize outdoor particle pollution levels: Carpool, telecommute, reduce trips, or take public transportation Slow down if driving on dirt roads Stabilize loose soils
Levels of particle pollution can vary hour by hour and by location depending on wind conditions.
To view current and forecasted air quality levels, visit the South Coast Air Quality Management District website at aqmd.gov or download the mobile app at www.aqmd.gov/mobileapp. Additional details for this air quality alert may be available at www.aqmd.gov/advisory.
To view current and forecasted air quality levels, visit the Mojave Desert Air Quality Management District website at mdaqmd.ca.gov. Additional details for this air quality alert may be available at www.mdaqmd.ca.gov/advisories.
To view current and forecast air quality within Imperial County visit the Imperial County Air Quality website at http://www.imperialvalleyair.org/ or follow ICAPCD on Twitter, facebook or Instagram (@county_air).
entry.cap:areaDesc: Chuckwalla Mountains; Chiriaco Summit; Chuckwalla Valley

cap:parameter.value: AIR QUALITY ALERT DUE TO ELEVATED PARTICLE POLLUTION LEVELS FROM WINDBLOWN DUST

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 4 at 8:00PM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
entry.summary: Intermittent snow showers are expected across the high elevations of the North Carolina mountains through Friday. By Friday evening, accumulations ranging from a dusting to up to 3 inches are expected across much of the area above 3500 feet. Locally higher amounts of 6 inches or more are expected on the high peaks and ridge tops along the Tennessee border. Motorists traveling across the high elevations through Friday should use extra caution.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Madison; Yancey; Mitchell; Swain; Haywood; Graham

entry.title: High Wind Watch issued April 4 at 3:06PM AKDT until April 6 at 1:00PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Southwest winds 50 to 65 mph, becoming west on Saturday morning, with gusts up to 80 mph possible.
* WHERE...Central Aleutians.
* WHEN...From Friday evening through Saturday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...High winds could move loose debris, damage property, and cause power outages. Travel could be difficult.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Winds will increase Friday night out of the southwest and are most likely to peak during the early hours of Saturday morning. Although winds will begin to diminish later on through Saturday morning, they will shift out of the west. This is a favorable direction for strong winds in both Adak and Atka, so it is possible that the strongest winds of the event may instead be experienced during this time.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Central Aleutians

...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers and locations in Indiana...
Driftwood River near Edinburgh.
White River at Petersburg, Edwardsport, Newberry, Ravenswood, Elliston, and Spencer.
East Fork White River at Seymour.
...The Flood Warning is extended for the following river and location in Indiana...
White River at Hazleton.
.Ongoing minor flooding will continue along central Indiana rivers, with some locations on the lower White expected to continue to flood through Tuesday. The crest on the East Fork White is slightly past Columbus and the crest on the White is between the Indianapolis area and Spencer.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...White River at Elliston.
* WHEN...Until early Monday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 23.0 feet, Extensive flooding of agricultural lands begin.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:13 AM EDT Thursday the stage was 21.4 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 8:13 AM EDT Thursday was 21.4 feet. - Forecast...The river will rise to 22.5 feet just after midnight tonight. It will then fall below flood stage Sunday afternoon to 9.2 feet Tuesday evening. It will rise to 9.3 feet early Wednesday morning. It will then fall to 8.9 feet Saturday, April 13. It will then rise again but remain below flood stage. - Flood stage is 18.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Daviess, IN; Greene, IN; Knox, IN

entry.title: High Wind Watch issued April 4 at 4:04PM MDT until April 7 at 12:00PM MDT by NWS Denver CO
entry.summary:
* WHAT...West winds 35 to 45 mph with gusts up to 75 mph possible. Localized gusts up to 100 mph are possible in and immediately adjacent to the foothills.
* WHERE...Front Range Mountains and Foothills, I-25 Corridor, and adjacent plains.
* WHEN...From Saturday morning through Sunday morning.
* IMPACTS...Damaging winds could blow down trees and power lines, and create roof and fence damage. Scattered power outages are possible. Travel could be difficult, especially for high profile vehicles, and areas of blowing dust can be expected east of I-25.
Fire danger will also be high and rapid rates of fire spread will be possible across the plains due to the strength of winds. While some precipitation is possible, the level of fire danger Saturday into Sunday will depend on exactly where and how much falls.
entry.cap:areaDesc: South and East Jackson/Larimer/North and Northeast Grand/Northwest Boulder Counties Above 9000 Feet; South and Southeast Grand/West Central and Southwest Boulder/Gilpin/Clear Creek/Summit/North and West Park Counties Above 9000 Feet; Larimer and Boulder Counties Between 6000 and 9000 Feet; Jefferson and West Douglas Counties Above 6000 Feet/Gilpin/Clear Creek/Northeast Park Counties Below 9000 Feet; Central and Southeast Park County; Larimer County Below 6000 Feet/Northwest Weld County; Boulder And Jefferson Counties Below 6000 Feet/West Broomfield County; North Douglas County Below 6000 Feet/Denver/West Adams and Arapahoe Counties/East Broomfield County; Elbert/Central and East Douglas Counties Above 6000 Feet; Northeast Weld County; Central and South Weld County; Morgan County; Central and East Adams and Arapahoe Counties; North and Northeast Elbert County Below 6000 Feet/North Lincoln County; Southeast Elbert County Below 6000 Feet/South Lincoln County

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 4 at 2:29PM PDT by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
* Gusty southwest winds will decrease this evening for Mono and Mineral counties. Gusts will continue along Sierra ridges into the overnight hours, becoming lighter by Friday morning. Impacts include difficult backcountry and lake recreation, bumpy airplane rides, and gusty cross winds for high-profile vehicles, especially along US-395, US-95, and I-580. Wind gusts along the Sierra crest will exceed 80 mph through this evening.
* Snow showers will increase over the Tahoe Basin this afternoon. Roads will be slick in the Sierra, especially at night. The higher April sun angle will limit accumulations during the daytime hours. Prepare for possible delays if your plans include travel across the Sierra. Total snow accumulations: Above 7000 feet in Greater Lake Tahoe: greater than 6 inches on the west side of Lake Tahoe and 1-2 inches in the Carson Range. Lowest Nevada valleys: light snow showers, but no accumulation.
* Cold air has settled into the area with daytime temperatures 15-20 degrees below normal Friday with slight warming over the weekend. Hard freezes are expected each night this weekend beginning tonight. Now is the time to protect sensitive plants and wrap exposed irrigation systems.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Surprise Valley California; Lassen-Eastern Plumas-Eastern Sierra Counties; Greater Lake Tahoe Area; Mono; Mineral and Southern Lyon Counties; Greater Lake Tahoe Area; Greater Reno-Carson City-Minden Area; Western Nevada Basin and Range including Pyramid Lake; Northern Washoe County

entry.title: Avalanche Warning issued April 4 at 5:20PM EDT by NWS Gray ME
entry.summary:
AVWGYX
The following message is transmitted at the request of the Forest Service Mount Washington Avalanche Center, Gorham NH.
The US Forest Service Mount Washington Avalanche Center has issued a backcountry avalanche warning. This avalanche warning does not apply to operating ski areas.
* WHAT...A significant winter storm, bringing the possibility of 2 to 3 ft of snow and strong wind to the higher summits in the Presidential Range, will create dangerous avalanche conditions. Travel in or near avalanche terrain is not recommended.
* WHERE...The Presidential Range avalanche forecast area, including steep, open terrain in the mountains that are bounded by US Rt 2, US Rt 302, and NH Rt 16. This includes hiking trails that traverse across steep terrain like Summer Lion Head trail. Similar avalanche danger may exist at locations outside the coverage area where steep, open terrain exists that has collected wind drifted snow.
* WHEN...In effect from Thu 04:00 EDT to Fri 04:00 EDT.
* IMPACTS...Natural and human-triggered avalanches that are large enough to bury multiple people, snap trees, and destroy structures are very likely to occur. These large avalanches may run far down their historic paths into the areas that are typically considered safe zones.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Southern Coos

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued April 4 at 3:58PM CDT by NWS Houston/Galveston TX
entry.summary:
AQAHGX
The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) has issued an Ozone Action Day for the Houston, Galveston, and Brazoria area for Friday, April 5, 2024.
Atmospheric conditions are expected to be favorable for producing high levels of ozone pollution in the Houston, Galveston, and surrounding areas on Friday. You can help prevent ozone pollution by sharing a ride, walking, riding a bicycle, taking your lunch to work, avoiding drive through lanes, conserving energy and keeping your vehicle properly tuned.
For more information on ozone: Ozone: The Facts www.tceq.texas.gov/airquality/monops/ozonefacts.html EPA AirNow: www.airnow.gov/?city=Houston&state=TX&country=USA Take Care of Texas: www.takecareoftexas.org/conservation-tips/keep-our-air-clean
entry.cap:areaDesc: Inland Harris; Inland Brazoria; Inland Galveston; Coastal Harris; Coastal Brazoria; Coastal Galveston; Brazoria Islands; Galveston Island; Bolivar Peninsula

entry.title: Red Flag Warning issued April 4 at 2:54PM MDT until April 5 at 9:00PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT 11 AM TO 9 AM FRIDAY FOR THE NORTHWEST PLATEAU, RIO GRANDE VALLEY, SANDIA AND MANZANO MOUNTAINS BELOW SNOWPACK AND ALL OF EASTERN NEW MEXICO DUE TO STRONG WINDS, LOW HUMIDITY AND AN UNSTABLE ATMOSPHERE...
...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT SATURDAY AFTERNOON AND EARLY EVENING FOR THE MIDDLE RIO GRANDE VALLEY AND ALL OF EASTERN NEW MEXICO DUE TO STRONG WINDS AND LOW HUMIDITY...
.Widespread critical fire weather conditions are expected on Friday as winds increase ahead of an approaching storm system. These strong winds combined with low humidity will allow for rapid fire spread in dry and receptive fuels. Strong south to southwest winds will peak during the afternoon hours, but will remain elevated through the evening and overnight Friday night. A strong cold front will surge from west to east early Saturday. Very strong westerly winds will develop behind the front and with continued low humidity values, critical fire weather conditions are expected once again on Saturday for the Rio Grande Valley and all of eastern New Mexico.
* AREA AND TIMING...This includes the Northwest Plateau (Zone 101), Upper Rio Grande Valley and Lower Chama River Valley (Zone 121), and the Sandia and Manzano Mountains below snowpack (Zone 124) from late Friday morning through Friday evening.
* 20 FOOT WINDS...South to southwest 25 to 35 mph with gusts between 45 and 60 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...Minimum values between 10 and 15 percent.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northwest Plateau; Upper Rio Grande Valley and Lower Chama River Valley; Sandia and Manzano Mountains

cap:parameter.value: RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 11 AM TO 9 PM MDT FRIDAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 4 at 3:46PM EDT by NWS Burlington VT
entry.summary:
Recent heavy snowfall combined with the pre-existing state of the snowpack has created the potential for avalanches in the back country of the Green Mountains near Smugglers Notch in Vermont and the High Peaks of the northern Adirondacks in New York.
Outdoor enthusiasts heading into the back country on Friday to snowshoe or ski, need to be aware of the avalanche danger, the risks involved and take the appropriate precautions.
Avoid avalanche prone areas such as steep, unstable slopes or downslope areas from vulnerable locations. If skiing, hiking, or snowshoeing stay on marked trails and avoid exposed open slopes.
Monitor announcements from local or state officials about the possible risk of avalanche and stay tuned to the latest National Weather Service forecasts and statements.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Western Essex; Lamoille; Eastern Chittenden

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued April 4 at 3:06PM EDT by NWS Jackson KY
entry.summary:
Mixed rain and snow showers in the lower elevations and snow showers above 2500 feet will impact the area tonight into late Friday morning. Above 2500 feet on Pine Mountain and Black Mountain, some light accumulations of a dusting to around an inch are forecast, generally on grassy and elevated surfaces. However, during the heavier snow showers, some roadways above 2500 feet could become snow- or slush-covered for a time, with this most probable on roadways above 3000 feet that cross Black Mountain in Harlan County such as KY 179 and KY 160. Other roadways that may be affected by winter travel include US 119, US 421, KY 38, KY 2010, and the Little Shepherd Trail.
If traveling across Pine and Black Mountains tonight through Friday morning, expect some slick spots. Slow down and allow extra time to reach your destination.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Harlan; Letcher

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued April 3 at 4:58PM PDT by NWS San Diego CA
entry.summary:
The South Coast AQMD has issued an air quality alert due to increased particle pollution from blowing dust. The air quality alert is in effect 11 AM Thursday through 5 AM Friday.
In areas directly impacted by high levels of windblown dust, limit your exposure by remaining indoors with windows and doors closed and avoiding vigorous physical activity. Run your air conditioner or an air purifier. If temperatures allow, avoid using whole house fans or swamp coolers that bring in outside air.
Exposure to high particle pollution levels can cause serious health problems, including asthma attacks, heart and lung disease symptoms, and increased risk of respiratory infections. People with heart or lung diseases should follow their doctor's advice for dealing with episodes of unhealthy air quality. Children, older adults, and people with respiratory or heart disease should avoid prolonged exposure and strenuous activities when particle pollution levels are high.
To help minimize outdoor particle pollution levels: * Carpool, telecommute, reduce trips, or take public transportation * Slow down if driving on dirt roads * Stabilize loose soils
Levels of particle pollution can vary hour by hour and by location depending on wind conditions.
To view current and forecasted air quality levels, visit the South Coast Air Quality Management District website at aqmd.gov or download the mobile app at www.aqmd.gov/mobileapp. Additional details for this air quality alert may be available at www.aqmd.gov/advisory.
To view current and forecasted air quality levels, visit the Mojave Desert Air Quality Management District website at mdaqmd.ca.gov. Additional details for this air quality alert may be available at www.mdaqmd.ca.gov/advisories.
To view current and forecast air quality within Imperial County visit the Imperial County Air Quality website at http://www.imperialvalleyair.org/ or follow ICAPCD on Twitter, facebook or Instagram (@county_air).

entry.title: Air Quality Alert issued April 3 at 3:22PM MST by NWS Phoenix AZ
entry.summary:
The South Coast AQMD has issued an air quality alert due to increased particle pollution from blowing dust. The air quality alert is in effect 11 AM Thursday through 5 AM Friday.
In areas directly impacted by high levels of windblown dust, limit your exposure by remaining indoors with windows and doors closed and avoiding vigorous physical activity. Run your air conditioner or an air purifier. If temperatures allow, avoid using whole house fans or swamp coolers that bring in outside air.
Exposure to high particle pollution levels can cause serious health problems, including asthma attacks, heart and lung disease symptoms, and increased risk of respiratory infections. People with heart or lung diseases should follow their doctor's advice for dealing with episodes of unhealthy air quality. Children, older adults, and people with respiratory or heart disease should avoid prolonged exposure and strenuous activities when particle pollution levels are high.
To help minimize outdoor particle pollution levels: Carpool, telecommute, reduce trips, or take public transportation Slow down if driving on dirt roads Stabilize loose soils
Levels of particle pollution can vary hour by hour and by location depending on wind conditions.
To view current and forecasted air quality levels, visit the South Coast Air Quality Management District website at aqmd.gov or download the mobile app at www.aqmd.gov/mobileapp. Additional details for this air quality alert may be available at www.aqmd.gov/advisory.
To view current and forecasted air quality levels, visit the Mojave Desert Air Quality Management District website at mdaqmd.ca.gov. Additional details for this air quality alert may be available at www.mdaqmd.ca.gov/advisories.
To view current and forecast air quality within Imperial County visit the Imperial County Air Quality website at http://www.imperialvalleyair.org/ or follow ICAPCD on Twitter, facebook or Instagram (@county_air).

entry.title: Flood Warning issued April 3 at 12:28PM CDT until April 13 at 10:00AM CDT by NWS Paducah KY
entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Paducah has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Indiana...Illinois...
Wabash River at New Harmony
.Runoff from recent heavy rain over the Ohio River Valley will cause minor flooding to develop along the Wabash River at New Harmony. The river is forecast to rise above flood stage Sunday morning and crest near 16.2 feet Wednesday, April 10.
For the Wabash River...including New Harmony...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Wabash River at New Harmony.
* WHEN...From late Saturday night to Saturday, April 13.
* IMPACTS...At 15.0 feet, The river overflows low ground on the Illinois side.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:30 AM CDT Wednesday the stage was 4.4 feet. - Bankfull stage is 12.0 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage early Sunday morning to a crest of 16.2 feet Wednesday, April 10. It will then fall below flood stage Saturday, April 13. - Flood stage is 15.0 feet.

entry.title: Avalanche Watch issued April 2 at 1:37PM EDT by NWS Gray ME
entry.summary:
AVAGYX
The following message is transmitted at the request of the Forest Service Mount Washington Avalanche Center, Gorham NH.
The US Forest Service Mount Washington Avalanche Center has issued a backcountry avalanche watch. This avalanche watch does not apply to operating ski areas.
* WHAT...A significant winter storm, bringing the possibility of 30+ inches of snow and strong wind to the higher summits in the Presidential Range, will create dangerous avalanche conditions.
* WHERE...The Presidential Range avalanche forecast area, including but not limited to Tuckerman Ravine, Huntington Ravine, Gulf of Slides, Great Gulf, King Ravine, Burt Ravine, Ammonoosuc Ravine, Oakes Gulf and steep, open terrain in the mountains that are bounded by US Rt 2, US Rt 302, and NH Rt 16. This includes hiking trails that traverse across steep terrain like Summer Lion Head trail. Similar avalanche danger may exist at locations outside of the coverage area where steep, open terrain exists that has collected drifted snow.
* WHEN...In effect from Tue 16:00 EDT to Fri 16:00 EDT.
* IMPACTS... Large, destructive avalanches are likely to occur naturally and spontaneously and will exist throughout steep terrain including hiking trails. These avalanches may be large enough to bury multiple people, do significant damage to trees or buildings, and will likely run far down in paths or areas that are normally safe zones. Precipitation rates are forecast to be heavy, with 1-2 inches of snow falling per hour at times and visibility limited.
